Package mms.storage

Class Storage

Object
Storage
Direct Known Subclasses:
Bag, Box, MovingTruck
public abstract class Storage extends Object
Represents some form of storage entity.

A storage class contains and manages an internal inventory of Packable items.

A storage entity can only contain so much before the storage unit becomes full.

Implement this for Assignment 1

      public Storage(double width, double height, double length) throws IllegalArgumentException

      height - the height of the storage in cm
      length - the length of the storage in cm
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if width <= 0 or height <= 0 or length <= 0

    • getCapacity

      public int getCapacity()
      Returns the capacity of the storage.

      The capacity is determined by the following table, and is based on the Size and multiplier set by the particular storage class.

      Storage capacity level table
      Storage Size Associated capacity
      SMALL3 × multiplier
      MEDIUM5 × multiplier
      LARGE10 × multiplier
      Where multiplier is the value returned by getMultiplier()
      Returns:
      capacity of this storage
      See Also:
      • getMultiplier()
      Implement this for Assignment 1

    • getMultiplier

      protected abstract int getMultiplier()
      Returns the multiplier of the particular storage type.
      Returns:
      multiplier of this storage
      Implement this for Assignment 1

    • pack

      public void pack(Packable item) throws PackingException
      Adds an item to the storages internal list.

      If the storage is at capacity or adding the item to this storage causes any 2 of the sum of the elements' width, height or length to be greater than the width, height or length (respectively) of this storage than an exception should be thrown and no action should be taken.
      That is, exceeding one sum is ok but exceeding 2 should cause an exception.

      This method declares to throw a PackingException to allow subclasses to throw additional exceptions to the same type.

      Parameters:
      item - the item to add to the list
      Throws:
      StorageFullException - if the current elements size >= the capacity of this storage or if two of the following are true:
      ∑ widths of items in the storage + width of new item > storage width,
      ∑ heights of items in the storage + height of new item > storage height,
      ∑ lengths of items in the storage + length of new item > storage length
      PackingException
      Implement this for Assignment 1

    • unpack

      public Packable unpack()
      Removes an item from storages internal list.

      The list should be unpacked in a First In, First Out (FIFO) format.

      Returns:
      item at the first index in this storages list; null if the list is empty
      Implement this for Assignment 1

    • getOccupiedCapacity

      public int getOccupiedCapacity()
      Returns how many elements are currently in the storage's list.
      Returns:
      number of elements in this storage
      Implement this for Assignment 1

    • toString

      public String toString()
      Returns the human-readable string representation of the storage.

      The format of the string to return is: 

      'class' ('width', 'height', 'length') size

      Where:

      • 'class' is the storage's instance class simple name (see Object.getClass()).
      • 'width' is this storage's width in cm.
      • 'height' is this storage's height in cm.
      • 'length' is this storage's length in cm.
      • 'size' is this storage's size.

      The storage's width, height and length should be formatted to two decimal places.

      For example this method should generate the following for an instance of the Box class: 

      Box (5.6, 5.6, 5) MEDIUM
      Overrides:
      toString in class Object
      Returns:
      string representation of this storage
      See Also:
      • Box.toString()
      Implement this for Assignment 1

    • toString

      public String toString(int level) throws IllegalArgumentException
      Returns the human-readable string representation of the storage and it's elements.

      The format of the string to return is: 

       'tabs''class' ('width', 'height', 'length') size
 'elementTabs''element1'
 'elementTabs''element2'
 ...
 'elementTabs''elementN'

      Where:

      • 'level' is the specified number of "tab" characters (see parameters).
      • 'tabs' is 'level' "tab" character(s)
        (i.e. if level == 1 then there would be one "tab" character).
      • 'class' is the storage's instance class simple name (see Object.getClass()).
      • 'width' is this storage's width in cm.
      • 'height' is this storage's height in cm.
      • 'length' is this storage's length in cm.
      • 'size' is this storage's size
      • 'elementX' is the human-readable string representation of this storages Xth element, if it exists, where elements are appended in insertion order
        (i.e. the order that items were added to this storage by calling pack(Packable)).
        If the Xth element is an instance of the Storage class then the toString(int) method should be called with one higher level value as the parameter.
      • 'elementTabs' is 'level' + 1 "tab" character(s)
        (i.e. if level == 1 then there would be two "tab" characters).
        If the next 'elementX' is a Storage class then no "tab" characters are entered (as this is handled by the toString(int) as seen above).

      The storage's width, height and length should be formatted to two decimal places.

      System.lineSeparator() should be used to separate lines. There should be no newline at the end of the string.

      The below example contains double quotes on each line. These should NOT be present for the result but is to aid in showing the differences in whitespace with tabs. For example with a tab level of 2 (without the double quotes) and 2 elements1: 

       "        Box (5,5,5) MEDIUM"
 "            Book (Jane) Title: Basics of Java Programming (Non-Fiction)"
 "            Clothes (Bob) (SMALL, SHIRT)"
      An example with nested boxes is1: 
       "        Box (5,5,5) MEDIUM"
 "            Book (Jane) Title: Basics of Java Programming (Non-Fiction)"
 "            Box (2,2,2) SMALL"
 "                Clothes (Bob) (SMALL, SHIRT)"

      1 The human-readable represenation of the box is showing what would be generated from this class' toString() method, in actuality the Box.toString() of a Box would be called and might be different.

      Parameters:
      level - the number of tabs to indent
      Returns:
      string representation of this storage
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException
      See Also:
      • Box.toString()
      • Book.toString()
      • Book.toString()
      Implement this for Assignment 1
